text: in corduroy pants and a jaunty beige tweed blazer
I waited for Maihan in front of the iconic
located on a busy street in Deh Afghanan district
Men outfitted in Perahan Tunban suits with sandals criss-crossed each other on the sidewalk
Women sporting sheer chadors tied under their chins
and closed-toed shoes passed by uncovered females wearing sleeveless smock dresses
The little world around me was caught in that bell jar of rush-hour traffic
with cars finagling their way between innumerable bikes
A driver kicked a horse into a canter
pulling a garish ghadi down the street
After our first—and so far, only—night together
Maihan and I had continued to spend most days in each other's company
but rarely were we ever completely alone
We'd had no opportunity to speak to each other
as honestly as we had that night
there was so much that I longed to say
Even though he had made me no promises
The chill of the evening promised a cold winter was approaching
the dry wind chapped my lips and cut through my smart blazer
As the sun faded over the encircling mountain chains
shades of violet painted the sky
A sturdy man with a chinstrap beard wrapped in a camel wool patu
cast me a lecherous glare as he passed by
A tingling sensation crawled up and down my spine
but I promptly collected myself when I saw maihan approach
He smiled with a look of seraphic contentment
that glowed on his flawless skin
His windswept hair had been trimmed in layers
decked out in a designer button-down cardigan over a turtleneck
as he extended his arms to hug me
We made our way into the chai khana
We had grown accustomed to going out on our own by now
accented with Taloqan salt crystal lamps
and liver-red Chob Bash Ersari rugs
transformed the space into a romantic echo chamber
The fragrance emanating from incense sticks burning in anchored silver censers
A qawwali ensemble performed the spiritual song
with the lead singer playing a harmonium
two percussionists with a tabla and dholak
and a chorus of five men
Maihan and I were the youngest people there without the company of our parents
We walked through the arcade of arches
towards the back where a conference of men Jabbered away
as they reclined on carpet-covered takhts
Other customers sipped the aromatic kahwah
brewed from green tea leaves with saffron strands
We found a semi-secluded spot where we could converse freely
We both started with qai magh chai
I ordered a platter of lamb shami kebabs with masala fries
Maihan opted for a large plate of aushak dumplings
I'm very happy to be here with you
I want us to be together
I feel like I'm where I'm supposed to be#5C
I believe we're meant for each other
The words had been on my lips for weeks
I couldn't believe I had just uttered them
It's not so easy to have what we want
He appeared to bristle for a moment
but then smoothed out the gathered folds of his cardigan
I feel closer to you than I do to anybody
I wasn't entirely honest with you the night we were together
He looked down at his dumplings
The words shot out of him quickly
You told me about the girl
He fidgeted uncomfortably in his seat and went on
There were a couple of guys too
I know how I feel about you
I also know that my family would never accept it
whether I was more upset that he had had sex with men or women
Then he finally turned his eyes to me
I was serious about what I said to you that night
that I need to be a good son to my parents
But you are the perfect son
I want us to be together
My family and I are set to leave again for the winter recess
and we won't return until school starts up again in March
unsure what he meant by this
How does you leaving change anything between us
We can still write to each other
Maihan looked down at his half-eaten meal
I think it will be a good break for us
My time with you is fun and spontaneous
You make living in a dream sound so easy
But it's not as easy for me#5C
I've neglected my family these past weeks
there's school and sports and the art competition
I need to be focusing on other things
I reached out for Maihan's hand
that we could stay there the whole night
with no one we knew around
and finally say all the things that we felt for each other
his eyes filled with a mist of doubt and tenderness
until he became distracted by something across the room
Don't look now, but guess who walked in
Do you think they saw us
If they haven't seen us yet, they probably will
Maihan and I split the bill
left a tip for the waiter
a voice shouted over to us
We turned around to see the inquisitive features of Faiz
We sheepishly made our way over to him
How come you came here without me
We came over to your house earlier and knocked on your door
I was surprised to see how easily the lie came to him
Can we do dinner this weekend
Once we were outside the restaurant
I feel terrible about lying to Faiz
What else could we have done
Do you think he'd stop being friends with us if he knew
But it bothered me that i couldn’t be my authentic self
I felt a bitter taste in my mouth
I thought of Rustam and how he had made jokes about kuni-ha
despite leering at me in the showers
Afghans postulated about sadaqat and imandari
but these principles of honesty and integrity were impossible for us to uphold in our society
We had an apophthegm in Dari
and I understood that I had to keep myself away from danger
But I hated the tangled web of lies
I wanted to go home and tell Maadar and Baba
that Maihan and I loved each other
But even if they knew a lot about forbidden love
about standing up for their beliefs
they would never understand my feelings
I knew I would have to choose between my love for Baba
and my devotion to my Afghaniyat on one side
and my yearning for Maihan on the other
I wondered if he thought about the choices he had to make
